fields.label_text:
Grille from Chichester Cathedral
Wrought iron, with traces of the original gilding and red paint, beneath the present paint.
English; about 1250-1300
591-1896

Made for the retrochoir of Chichester cathedral from where it was removed during the restorations of the nineteenth century. The upper part of the grille incorporates a section decorated with stamped motifs from another and slightly later grille in Westminster Abbey made by Thomas de Leghtone in 1294.

GRILLE FROM CHICHESTER CATHEDRAL
Wrought iron, with traces of the original gilding and red paint, beneath the present paint
English; about 1250-1300
Made for the retrochoir of Chichester Cathedral, from where it was removed during the restorations of the nineteenth century. The upper part of the grille incorporates a section, decorated with stamped motifs from another and slightly later grille in Westminster Abbey, made by Thomas de Leghtone in 1294.

fields.descriptive_line: The Chichester Grille, iron, with stamped motifs, England, ca. 1250-1275

fields.name: Age of Chivalry: Art in Plantagenet England 1200-1400

fields.physical_description: The grille is composed of eight different-sized panels attached to a framework of plain iron bars surmounted by a row of spikes. The elements grouped in the panels are: Y scrolls  curled like rams' horns with a central stem; two sizes of spiral S scrolls; back-to-back C scrolls ending in circular terminals stamped with a crude fleur-de-lis and rosette, one on each side. The scrolled elements are collared to each other and to slender vertical bars which terminate in an open circlet. The collars used within each panel are small and neat with a circular cross section., while those attaching the panels to the main frame are crude and roughly clasped, indicating that the panels have been reassembled in their present frame. Traces of red paint and gilding were visible in 1896.
fields.dimensions: Height: 245 cm, Width: 304 cm, Depth: 4 cm
fields.title: The Chichester Grille
fields.label:
Grille from Chichester Cathedral
Wrought iron, with traces of the original gilding and red paint, beneath the present paint.

591-1896

Made for the retrochoir of Chichester cathedral from where it was removed during the restorations of the nineteenth century. The upper part of the grille incorporates a section decorated with stamped motifs from another and slightly later grille in Westminster Abbey made by Thomas de Leghtone in 1294.
GRILLE FROM CHICHESTER CATHEDRAL
Wrought iron, with traces of the original gilding and red paint, beneath the present paint
English; about 1250-1300
Made for the retrochoir of Chichester Cathedral, from where it was removed during the restorations of the nineteenth century. The upper part of the grille incorporates a section, decorated with stamped motifs from another and slightly later grille in Westminster Abbey, made by Thomas de Leghtone in 1294.
fields.location: Medieval and Renaissance, room 50b, case EXP
fields.public_access_description: This ironwork screen from Chichester cathedral, is an extremely rare survivor. The destruction of medieval church grilles in England has been almost complete, no examples remain in many of the main Cathedrals, great abbeys or churches which would once have had many such screens. The screen is an early type remarkable for an absence of symmetrical arrangement. Though much decayed and damaged, with the scrolls confused and displaced, the object represents a unique and priceless example of the grille-work used in the English cathedral in the thirteenth century.
fields.exhibition_history: Age of Chivalry: Art in Plantagenet England 1200-1400 (Royal Academy of Arts 06/11/1987-06/03/1988)
fields.bibliography:
Starkie Gardner. J <u>Ironwork Part I. From the earliest times to the end of the Medieval period </u> (London Board of Education, 1927) p74 plate no. 31, Marian Campbell, <U>An Introduction to Ironwork</U>, Victoria and Albert Museum, 1985, figure 15; <U>The Age of Chivalry</U>, Royal Academy of Arts, 1987-8, no.364 entry written by Dr Jane Geddes.
Vallance. A <u> Greater English Church Screens </u> (Clowes and Sons, 1947) p 60
Hobbs. M <u>Chichester Cathedral An Historical Survey </u> (Phillimore,1994) p.79 & p.148
Campbell, Marian, <u>An Introduction to Ironwork</u>, London: HMSO, 1985, p. 26, fig. 15
<u>Age of Chivalry: Art in Plantagenet England 1200-1400</u>, Alexander, J. and Binski, P. (eds), London: Weidenfeld and Nicholson, 1987, no. 364, p. 359
fields.history_note:
Originally from Chichester Cathedral choir where it may have been part of the "costly clausures" made to screen the tomb of Saint Richard in 1276.When the shrine was demolished in 1538, the "clausures" were removed and may have been reassembled in their present frame at that date.

The screen was bought by a marine store dealer during 19th century restorations (possibly either in 1829 as part of the major repairs and improvements which were carried out in the choir area (M.Hobbs) or after 1861 when the central tower was rebuilt after collapse (Starkie-Gardener). Bought by the Duke de Moro, then bought by the Victoria & Albert Museum. in 1896.

A sketch of the screen as it stood in 1872 may be seen in the Transactions of the Royal Institute of British Architects for 1891, but no representation of it before the collapse of the tower in 1861 has been published.

Historical significance: The screen is an extremely rare survivor. The destruction of medieval church grilles in England has been almost complete, no examples remain in the Cathedrals of York, Durham ,Chester Peterborough, Ripon, Lichfield, Norwich, Worcester, Hereford, Gloucester, Exeter, Manchester, Bristol, Carlisle nor any of the great abbeys or churches. A fragment shows that St Albans once possessed such a grille-work and the grilles to St Anselm's chapel in Canterbury are survivors of a type. 

This grille is an early type remarkable for an absence of symmetrical arrangement. Though much decayed and damaged, with the scrolls confused and displaced, the object represents a unique and priceless example of the grille-work used in the English cathedral in the thirteenth century.
fields.production_note: The grille incorporates a section of ironwork with stamped motifs from another and slightly later grille in Westminster Abbey made by Thomas de Leghtone in 1294.
fields.historical_context_note: Similar elements of the S and Y scrolls are found on many French grilles of the late twelfth  and early thirteenth centuries, at St Aventin, Artonne, Billom, Conques and Le Mans. Another panel from Chichester in the V&A collection (592A-1896) constructed in the same way, has S scrolls with stamped terminals. The same S and Y elements were also recorded on a grille at Boxgrove Priory, Sussex in 1825 (J.Buckler, British library. Add. ms 36433, ff.629,641) now lost.
